fields.description:
*What is full stack developer?*

Is it reasonable to expect mere mortals to have mastery over every facet of the development stack? Probably not, but Facebook can ask for it. I was told at OSCON by a Facebook employee that they only hire ‘Full Stack’ developers.  Well, what does that mean?

!2404979742-Capture.PNG|thumbnail!

To me, a Full Stack Developer is someone with familiarity in each layer, if not mastery in many and a genuine interest in all software technology.

Good developers who are familiar with the entire stack know how to make life easier for those around them. This is why I’m so against silos in the work place. Sure, politics and communication challenges get in the way in large organizations. I think the point Facebook is going for with their hiring policy is, if smart people use their heads and their hearts, a better product gets built in less time.

layers of the full stack:

Server, Network, and Hosting Environment.\\
This involves understanding what can break and why, taking no resource for granted.\\
Appropriate use of the file system, cloud storage, network resources, and an understanding of data redundancy and availability is necessary.\\
How does the application scale given the hardware constraints?\\
What about multi-threading and race conditions? Guess what, you won’t see those on your development machine, but they can and do happen in the real world.\\
Full stack developers can work side by side with DevOps. The system should provide useful error messages and logging capabilities. DevOps will see the messages before you will, so make them count.\\
Data Modeling\\
If the data model is flawed, the business logic and higher layers start to need strange (ugly) code to compensate for corner cases the data model doesn’t cover.\\
Full stack developers know how to create a reasonably normalized relational model, complete with foreign keys, indexes, views, lookup tables, etc.\\
Full stack developers are familiar with the concept of non-relational data stores and understand where they shine over relational data stores.
fields.summary: This is Test

fields.description:
The link

http://chart.apis.google.com/chart?cht=lc&chs=800x200&chco=326A9E&chxt=x,y&chtt=Test&chxr=1,0,55&chds=0,55&chxs=1N_s_&chls=3&chm=o,0066FF,0,-1,10,0&chd=t:0,10,8,12,1,7,9,2,32,14,11,55&chxl=0:|Jul2013|Aug2013|Sep2013|Oct2013|Nov2013|Dec2013|Jan2014|Mar2014|Mar2014|Apr2014|May2014|Jun2014

is not parsed when used for an image in the readme. The src attribute of the generated image tag is empty. I tried fixing it by encoding the 2 asterisks (*) in the link. With that change the link then works on stackoverflow.com and on http://dillinger.io/. On both these sites the image is then displayed correctly. However not on bitbucket. I also tried to encode further character but to no avail. It just did not work. Since this works for other markdown viewers I consider this a bug.

fields.description:
Recently we reviewed a pull request and didn't think anything of a binary file that was modified at one commit, then "unmodified" at another commit in the branch.

After the branch was merged, we found that the binary file had been corrupted. This was introduced in the second commit. The pull request had said "File contents unchanged." so reviewers expected no corruption, but in fact, the file had been changed.

If you need the URLs to our pull request, don't hesitate to contact me.

An image of what the PR displays is below:\\
!3168758622-no%20changes.PNG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: According to Pull request, "File contents unchanged." for a binary file, but it was actually changed

fields.description:
Hi @evzijst & co!

While chewing wurst, @mg claimed that pull requests handled updates with modified history badly.

Real world testing on https://bitbucket.org/pypy/pypy/pull-request/254/ confirms it.

My fork is non publishing. I pushed a change, made a PR, got feedback, modified my changeset, and pushed an extra head with force. When editing the PR it shows the new changeset in the list. But when I save it, the actual PR still uses the old PR.

I guess it is fair enough if it only supports "extending" the PR but not "removing" changesets from it ... but then it should show that in the edit ui.

However, I manually stripped the old head. That "broke" the PR more than expected. From what @brodie had told me I thought you stored the context together with the comments ... but since bb no longer shows any context after the changeset has been stripped, I assume that isn't the case.

Anyway, after that I could update the PR to the new changeset.
fields.summary: Problems updating pull requests

fields.description:

fields.summary: Add support for JIRA Markup (BB-11025)

fields.description:
On the new interface when we create a new empty repository :

* all users with Write or Admin permissions don't have the "Watch" button on the overview page nor the repository URL (but the latter can still be found when clicking on the Clone section)
* users with "Read Only" permission have the "Watch" button and the repository URL directly on the Overview page.

It's not critical but it's annoying as we cannot directly add the repository on SourceTree from the bookmarks as long as it's not watched.

Here is an attachment of the Overview page with users having Write permissions. The top right corner lacks the usual component letting people watch the repository and the repository URL
fields.summary: Cannot "Watch" an empty repository when having Write/Admin permissions (BB-11028)

fields.description:
I had files with win-1251 encoding. These files were shown as «binary» in web-interface. That is not a problem per se, since we can define binary file as «file which is not UTF-8 compliant».

The problem appeared when I converted these files to UTF-8. For this commit these files are listed in the list «Files changed», but differences for the files are displayed as «File contents unchanged». That can make me think that files are really not changed.

Moreover, for one short file the differences were displayed, and they look like that I changed readable to non-readable text (but in fact I changed non-readable to readable).

P.S. In SourceTree differences are displayed correctly.
fields.summary: Diff shown wrong when file encoding is changed (win-1251 -> UTF-8)

fields.description:
Hello,\\
I have multiple projects that use all the same deployment key. When I create a new project (which happens once per month), I need to connect to my deployment server and fetch the key, which is a hassle for me. Could you please add an option to "share deployment keys"?

You could create a section on one's account page to add "deployment keys". These keys won't be used by default for all project, instead, there should be an option to import these keys from the project's deployment key view.\\
In addition, there should be an optional checkbox which allows updating the key automatically (i.e. when I update the key in my profile, the key will be updated on all my projects, if enabled). This is extremely handy if you need to move to another server (and don't want to keep the old ssh keys), or if your keys get compromised (aka. Heartbleed).

I think this could save some of us a lot of time and it is extremely handy to just import deployment keys instead of getting them for the server.
fields.summary: Deployment Key Library (BB-11027)

fields.description:
I see that there is alot of people having the same issue, is the only way to remove a failed repo to ask bitbucket's support?

Anyway, could you remove:

https://bitbucket.org/numedia/uplayer and https://bitbucket.org/mpare/uplayer

Thanks
fields.summary: Can't remove repositories that failed importation

fields.description:
Currently, I'm told only the first line of the commit message is what is being sent via email to watchers of the repos.  This seems like a bug.

As a manager (and my boss the VP) we're different users and have a different user experience expectation when it comes to email messages.  The entire commit message should be there for review so as not to force an extra click, load and review of said message.

I'd understand if you only wish to allow the first 240 characters or so, but at least have a "..read more.." type of link to give us users a UI notification in the email message that you've truncated the commit message.

Still - I'd rather see the whole message.  It helps me and my team.
fields.summary: Display visual cue in email commit notifications if commit message is truncated (BB-11018)

fields.description:
Hello,

Do you can help-me?

I need know how many commits my branch behind master. I see in bitbucket web site have feature "Sync now". What command you run in GIT to return this value?

What command you run in GIT to synchronize (Sync branch)?

Please see image in attachment.

Thank you.
fields.summary: Knowing how many commits behind master?

fields.description:
I am unable to sync a forked git repo until a local change is been committed and the local branch is out of sync.

What should happen is that the remote (source) repo changes should show up even if a local commit has not happened.
fields.summary: unable to sync a forked git repo until local change is made

fields.summary: Repository unavailable and can't delete it

fields.description:
Following on from https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Mark+up+comments%2C+issues%2C+and+commit+messages?focusedCommentId=590261896#comment-590261896

It's easy right now to "link" to an existing commit if you know the commit id - the SHA-1 hash is automatically detected and hyperlinked. However as far as I know there's no way to do the same with a tag reference. Instead, one has to look up the associated SHA-1 and use that instead, which is awkward (and fixed, although I know tags aren't supposed to be moved).

What I'd like to see is a syntax that allows a tag to be specified, perhaps something like this example:

"This regression was previously fixed in tag:release_1_2_3"

(would automatically hyperlink to whichever commit had that tag on it).

I'm not sure whether it would link to the actual tag instance, or to the associated commit. Perhaps the former, as some tags may be annotated, but the most likely use-case is that the user actually wants to link to the associated commit.

For that matter, being able to link to branch references would be useful too (such that they follow the head of the branch):

"This issue should be addressed on branch:bugfix_12345"

Also, I'm thinking Issue comments primarily, but being able to specify these in commit messages makes sense since commit messages often end up as an Issue comment anyway.
fields.summary: Enable linking to tag and branch references from issue comments and commit messages (BB-11019)
